title: BadGraph: A Backdoor Attack Against Latent Diffusion Model for Text-Guided Graph Generation
summary: This paper introduces BadGraph, a novel backdoor attack method targeting latent diffusion models used for text-guided graph generation. By poisoning training data with textual triggers, BadGraph covertly implants vulnerabilities that compel the model to generate attacker-specified subgraphs during inference when triggers are present, while maintaining normal performance on clean inputs. The research demonstrates high attack success rates with low poisoning rates, highlighting significant security risks for applications like drug discovery.

title: Predicting Protein-Nucleic Acid Flexibility Using Persistent Sheaf Laplacians
summary: This paper introduces the Persistent Sheaf Laplacian (PSL) framework for accurately predicting atomic B-factors, which characterize the flexibility of protein-nucleic acid complexes. Integrating multiscale analysis, algebraic topology, and sheaf theory, PSL significantly outperforms traditional and existing multiscale models in capturing complex biomolecular interactions. The method achieved up to a 21% improvement in Pearson correlation coefficient for B-factor prediction, highlighting its robustness and potential for broader applications in structural biology and drug design.

title: Acoustic Emission Cascade Predicting Progression to Failure of Rock and Bone
summary: This paper identifies an "Acoustic Emission (AE) cascade" as a reliable predictor of impending failure in quasi-brittle materials like rock and bone. By monitoring the inverse AE energy rate, the study demonstrates that this cascade provides a crucial warning period before material fracture, with significant implications for preventing patient injury in medical settings.

title: ACS-SegNet: An Attention-Based CNN-SegFormer Segmentation Network for Tissue Segmentation in Histopathology
summary: This paper introduces ACS-SegNet, a novel attention-based deep learning model designed for precise semantic tissue segmentation in histopathological images. By integrating convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and vision transformers (ViTs) with attention-driven feature fusion within a dual-encoder architecture, the model achieved superior performance. Evaluated on two public datasets (GCPS and PUMA), ACS-SegNet outperformed state-of-the-art benchmarks, offering a significant advancement for automated image analysis in computer-aided diagnosis.

title: Empathic Prompting: Non-Verbal Context Integration for Multimodal LLM Conversations
summary: This paper introduces "Empathic Prompting," a novel framework that enhances multimodal human-AI interaction by integrating implicit non-verbal emotional cues into Large Language Model (LLM) conversations. The system uses a facial expression recognition service to capture user emotions and embeds this affective information as contextual signals during LLM prompting, aiming for more fluid and contextually aligned dialogues without explicit user control. A preliminary evaluation (N=5) demonstrated consistent integration of non-verbal input into coherent LLM outputs and improved conversational fluidity.

title: Automated Extraction of Fluoropyrimidine Treatment and Treatment-Related Toxicities from Clinical Notes Using Natural Language Processing
summary: This research developed and evaluated various Natural Language Processing (NLP) methods to automatically extract fluoropyrimidine treatment and associated toxicity information from unstructured clinical notes. The study found that Large Language Model (LLM)-based approaches, particularly with error-analysis prompting, significantly outperformed traditional machine learning, deep learning, and rule-based methods, achieving perfect F1 scores for both treatment and toxicity extraction.

title: Optimizing Clinical Fall Risk Prediction: A Data-Driven Integration of EHR Variables with the Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool
summary: This study optimized the Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool (JHFRAT) by integrating additional Electronic Health Record (EHR) variables using a data-driven Constrained Score Optimization (CSO) modeling approach. Analyzing over 54,000 inpatient admissions, the CSO model significantly improved fall risk prediction (AUC-ROC 0.91) compared to the standard JHFRAT (AUC-ROC 0.86). This robust methodology offers a stronger foundation for health systems to enhance inpatient fall prevention protocols and improve patient safety.
keywords: Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool

title: Diagnosing Visual Reasoning: Challenges, Insights, and a Path Forward
summary: Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) struggle with visual hallucinations and an over-reliance on textual priors when performing complex visual reasoning tasks. This paper addresses these issues by systematically diagnosing existing MLLMs and proposing an agent-based architecture that combines LLM reasoning with lightweight visual modules for iterative refinement. The new system achieves significant performance gains on benchmarks, matching or surpassing much larger models, highlighting the need for integrating specialized visual tools.

title: GRACE: GRaph-based Addiction Care prEdiction
summary: This paper introduces GRACE, a novel graph neural network (GNN) framework designed to automate the critical clinical decision of determining the appropriate locus of care for addiction patients. By formalizing this as a structured learning problem and employing a novel unbiased meta-graph approach, GRACE effectively addresses severe class imbalances in addiction datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in prediction accuracy for minority classes.

title: xTime: Extreme Event Prediction with Hierarchical Knowledge Distillation and Expert Fusion
summary: The xTime framework addresses the critical challenge of accurately forecasting extreme events in time series, which existing models often fail at due to data imbalance and neglect of intermediate event information. It leverages hierarchical knowledge distillation to transfer learning from common events and a mixture of experts (MoE) for dynamic prediction fusion, achieving significant improvements in forecasting accuracy for rare, high-impact events.

title: Better Tokens for Better 3D: Advancing Vision-Language Modeling in 3D Medical Imaging
summary: BTB3D (Better Tokens for Better 3D) introduces a novel causal convolutional encoder-decoder that unifies 2D/3D training to generate compact, frequency-aware volumetric tokens from high-resolution medical images. This approach significantly improves state-of-the-art performance in both automated report generation and text-to-CT synthesis by addressing the limitations of slice-wise tokenization and vision-language misalignment. The paper demonstrates that precise three-dimensional tokenization is crucial for scalable vision-language modeling in 3D medical imaging.

title: Deep Learning in Dental Image Analysis: A Systematic Review of Datasets, Methodologies, and Emerging Challenges
summary:
Efficient analysis and processing of dental images are crucial for dentists
to achieve accurate diagnosis and optimal treatment planning. However, dental
imaging inherently poses several challenges, such as low contrast, metallic
artifacts, and variations in projection angles. Combined with the subj...

title: Equitable Survival Prediction: A Fairness-Aware Survival Modeling (FASM) Approach
summary: This paper introduces Fairness-Aware Survival Modeling (FASM), an approach designed to mitigate algorithmic bias in survival prediction by addressing both intra-group and cross-group risk ranking disparities over time. Applied to SEER breast cancer prognosis data, FASM significantly enhances fairness without compromising discrimination performance, maintaining stable improvements over a 10-year horizon, particularly in the mid-term.

title: PSO-XAI: A PSO-Enhanced Explainable AI Framework for Reliable Breast Cancer Detection
summary: This research proposes PSO-XAI, an integrated framework leveraging customized Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) for intelligent feature selection, coupled with Explainable AI (XAI) methods, to improve breast cancer detection. Evaluated across 29 diverse machine learning models, the framework achieved a superior performance of 99.1% across all metrics while effectively reducing dimensionality and providing transparent, model-agnostic explanations. The study highlights the potential of combining swarm intelligence with XAI for robust and clinically meaningful breast cancer diagnosis.

title: The Dog the Cat Chased Stumped the Model: Measuring When Language Models Abandon Structure for Shortcuts
summary: This research introduces CenterBench, a novel dataset designed to meticulously evaluate when large language models (LLMs) abandon deep syntactic parsing for superficial semantic pattern matching. By testing models on center-embedded sentences with both plausible and implausible semantics across varying complexity levels, the study quantifies performance gaps, revealing that models increasingly rely on semantic shortcuts as linguistic complexity grows. The framework provides a critical tool to distinguish genuine structural understanding from associative reasoning in AI systems.

title: Fitness inference tested by in silico population genetics
summary: This research investigates the feasibility of inferring fitness parameters and the order of genotype fitness from population-wide, whole-genome, time-stratified genomic data. Using *in silico* simulations of populations evolving under natural selection, mutation, and recombination, the study successfully delineates specific parameter ranges where such inference is possible and where it is not. The work provides a crucial framework for assessing when fitness inference is robustly feasible from genomic surveillance data.

title: On Multiple Robustness of Proximal Dynamic Treatment Regimes
summary: This paper addresses the critical challenge of estimating optimal dynamic treatment regimes (DTRs) from observational data when the standard unconfoundedness assumption, crucial for causal inference, is violated. It introduces a proximal causal inference framework to overcome this limitation, proposing novel nonparametric identification methods, establishing a semiparametric efficiency bound, and developing a (K+1)-robust estimation method for learning optimal DTRs, with K representing the number of treatment stages.

title: MolBridge: Atom-Level Joint Graph Refinement for Robust Drug-Drug Interaction Event Prediction
summary: This paper introduces MolBridge, an atom-level joint graph refinement framework designed to overcome limitations in predicting Drug-Drug Interaction (DDI) events, particularly concerning complex molecular structures and fine-grained inter-drug relationships. By constructing a joint graph that integrates atomic structures of drug pairs and employing a structure consistency module, MolBridge effectively models both local and global interaction patterns, achieving superior and robust DDI prediction across diverse interaction types and scenarios.

title: Dynamic Weight Adjustment for Knowledge Distillation: Leveraging Vision Transformer for High-Accuracy Lung Cancer Detection and Real-Time Deployment
summary: This paper introduces FuzzyDistillViT-MobileNet, a novel model for high-accuracy lung cancer (LC) detection that utilizes dynamic fuzzy logic-driven knowledge distillation (KD) to adaptively adjust distillation weights, focusing on high-confidence regions in medical images. By employing a Vision Transformer (ViT-B32) as the instructor and MobileNet as the student, coupled with advanced image fusion and genetic algorithm-based optimization, the model achieves robust performance with 99.16% accuracy on histopathological images and 99.54% on CT-scan images, addressing the complexity and uncertainty in disease diagnosis for real-time deployment.

title: Identification and Debiased Learning of Causal Effects with General Instrumental Variables
summary: This paper introduces a general nonparametric framework for identifying and learning causal effects using multi-categorical or continuous instrumental variables (IVs) in situations where unobserved confounders bias treatment assignment. It proposes an additive IV framework to estimate mean potential outcomes and the average treatment effect (ATE) by employing a weighting function. The authors leverage debiased machine learning to construct consistent, asymptotically normal estimators with efficient influence functions, demonstrating its utility in simulations and real-world data.

title: Contrast-enhanced X-ray imaging of articular cartilage: reliability of a cationic contrast agent in combination with high-resolution peripheral quantitative computed tomography system
summary: This study investigated a novel approach for evaluating articular cartilage health by correlating proteoglycan content with mechanical properties. Using a cationic contrast agent (CA4+) with high-resolution peripheral quantitative computed tomography (HR-pQCT), the researchers successfully quantified proteoglycan content in healthy bovine articular cartilage and found significant correlations between the enhanced radiopacity and the tissue's viscoelastic mechanical response, suggesting its potential for early detection of cartilage degeneration.

title: Bias by Design? How Data Practices Shape Fairness in AI Healthcare Systems
summary: This paper addresses the critical barrier of biased training data hindering the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in healthcare. Drawing insights from the AI4HealthyAging project, it identifies historical, representation, and measurement biases within clinical data collection across various demographic and technical variables. The research concludes by offering practical recommendations to enhance the fairness and robustness of AI system design and data collection practices in healthcare.

title: Enhancing Security in Deep Reinforcement Learning: A Comprehensive Survey on Adversarial Attacks and Defenses
summary: This comprehensive survey addresses the critical issue of security and robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) systems, particularly in sensitive domains like smart healthcare. It introduces the DRL framework, analyzes security challenges posed by adversarial attacks, and proposes a classification framework for these attacks based on perturbation type and target. The paper details mainstream adversarial attack methods targeting various DRL components and systematically summarizes current defense strategies, discussing their respective advantages and shortcomings, before outlining future research directions.

title: DB-FGA-Net: Dual Backbone Frequency Gated Attention Network for Multi-Class Classification with Grad-CAM Interpretability
summary: This paper introduces DB-FGA-Net, a novel dual-backbone deep learning architecture combining VGG16 and Xception with a Frequency-Gated Attention Block for highly accurate and interpretable multi-class brain tumor classification. Notably, the model achieves state-of-the-art performance without data augmentation, demonstrating robustness, and integrates Grad-CAM for visual interpretability of tumor regions. A graphical user interface (GUI) is also developed to facilitate real-time clinical usability.

title: Classical Feature Embeddings Help in BERT-Based Human Mobility Prediction
summary: The paper introduces STaBERT (Semantic-Temporal aware BERT), a novel BERT-based model designed to significantly improve human mobility prediction by deeply integrating rich semantic context from Points of Interest (POIs) and derived temporal descriptors. This approach constructs a unified, semantically enriched representation for each location, addressing the limitations of prior models that underutilized such contextual information. Experimental results demonstrate substantial improvements in prediction accuracy for both single-city and multi-city scenarios.

title: Tri-Modal Severity Fused Diagnosis across Depression and Post-traumatic Stress Disorders
summary: This paper presents a unified tri-modal affective severity framework for simultaneously diagnosing co-occurring depression (5 classes) and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD, 3 classes) using interview text, audio, and facial signals. The framework fuses standardized features via a calibrated late fusion classifier to output graded severities and feature-level attributions. It significantly outperforms unimodal baselines, improves robustness under noisy conditions, and offers explainable insights crucial for clinical decision-making.

title: Towards Objective Obstetric Ultrasound Assessment: Contrastive Representation Learning for Fetal Movement Detection
summary: This paper introduces Contrastive Ultrasound Video Representation Learning (CURL), a novel self-supervised framework for objective and accurate fetal movement (FM) detection from extended ultrasound video recordings. By employing a dual-contrastive loss and a task-specific sampling strategy, CURL learns robust motion representations to overcome the subjectivity of traditional methods. Evaluated on an in-house dataset of 92 subjects, CURL achieved a sensitivity of 78.01% and an AUROC of 81.60%, demonstrating its potential for reliable prenatal health assessment.

title: Assessing the Feasibility of Early Cancer Detection Using Routine Laboratory Data: An Evaluation of Machine Learning Approaches on an Imbalanced Dataset
summary: This study evaluated the feasibility of early cancer detection in dogs using routine laboratory data and machine learning, specifically on the Golden Retriever Lifetime Study cohort. While a moderate ranking ability was achieved (AUROC=0.815), the optimal model demonstrated poor clinical classification performance (F1=0.25, PPV=0.15) and insufficient recall for reliable rule-out, concluding that the cancer signal in such data is too weak and confounded for clinical utility in isolation. The work establishes a performance ceiling for this data modality and highlights the need for multi-modal data integration.

title: A Structured Review and Quantitative Profiling of Public Brain MRI Datasets for Foundation Model Development
summary: This study systematically reviews and quantitatively profiles 54 public brain MRI datasets (over 538,031 images) to assess their suitability for developing foundation models. It reveals significant imbalances in dataset scale and disease coverage, alongside substantial image-level heterogeneity and persistent inter-dataset variability even after standardized preprocessing. The research ultimately demonstrates that harmonization alone is insufficient to eliminate inter-dataset bias, underscoring the need for advanced preprocessing-aware and domain-adaptive strategies.

title: Understanding Mechanistic Role of Structural and Functional Connectivity in Tau Propagation Through Multi-Layer Modeling
summary: This paper leverages a multi-layer graph diffusion model and extensive longitudinal neuroimaging data to elucidate the interacting roles of structural (SC) and functional (FC) connectivity in tau propagation within Alzheimer's disease (AD). It reveals a regionally asymmetric and dynamically shifting dominance of SC and FC over the disease course, linking these patterns to AD-associated gene expression and demonstrating how risk factors and amyloid deposition reshape tau spread.

title: Why Prototypes Collapse: Diagnosing and Preventing Partial Collapse in Prototypical Self-Supervised Learning
summary: This paper addresses the critical issue of 'partial prototype collapse' in prototypical self-supervised learning (SSL), where multiple learned prototypes converge to identical representations, diminishing their utility for guiding diverse representation learning. The authors diagnose the collapse as a consequence of joint optimization between encoders and prototypes, which promotes shortcut learning. They propose a novel, fully decoupled training strategy that models prototypes as a Gaussian mixture updated via an online EM-style procedure, independent of the encoder's loss, effectively eliminating collapse and leading to more diverse prototypes and stronger downstream performance.

title: Extending machine learning model for implicit solvation to free energy calculations
summary: This paper introduces Lambda Solvation Neural Network (LSNN), a novel graph neural network (GNN)-based implicit solvent model that addresses a key limitation of prior machine learning (ML) methods by training on both force-matching and derivatives of alchemical variables. This approach ensures that solvation free energies can be accurately and meaningfully compared across chemical species, achieving explicit-solvent level precision with a significant computational speedup. LSNN establishes a robust framework for accelerating drug discovery processes.

title: ShapeX: Shapelet-Driven Post Hoc Explanations for Time Series Classification Models
summary: ShapeX introduces a novel post-hoc explanation framework for time series classification models, addressing the limitations of existing methods that overlook the fundamental role of key shapelets. By segmenting time series into shapelet-driven components and applying Shapley values, ShapeX provides explanations that reveal causal relationships rather than mere correlations. Experimental results validate its superior performance in identifying relevant subsequences with enhanced precision and causal fidelity on both synthetic and real-world datasets.

title: Ask What Your Country Can Do For You: Towards a Public Red Teaming Model
summary:
AI systems have the potential to produce both benefits and harms, but without
rigorous and ongoing adversarial evaluation, AI actors will struggle to assess
the breadth and magnitude of the AI risk surface. Researchers from the field of
systems design have developed several effective sociotechnical ...

title: Endogenous Aggregation of Multiple Data Envelopment Analysis Scores for Large Data Sets
summary: This paper introduces a novel Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) approach, featuring two regularized models (SBM and GP-SBM), for dynamic, multi-dimensional efficiency evaluation in large datasets, incorporating both desirable and undesirable outputs. Applied to Ontario hospitals, these models effectively capture correlations among input/output variables and outperform traditional benchmarking methods. The approach provides both dimension-specific and an aggregate efficiency score, offering a comprehensive assessment of organizational effectiveness.

title: BrainPuzzle: Hybrid Physics and Data-Driven Reconstruction for Transcranial Ultrasound Tomography
summary: This paper introduces BrainPuzzle, a novel hybrid two-stage framework combining physics-based modeling and machine learning to achieve quantitative transcranial ultrasound tomography. It addresses the significant challenges of skull-induced signal degradation and impractical full-aperture arrays by utilizing reverse time migration to generate robust structural fragments, which are then fused into an accurate speed-of-sound (SoS) map by a transformer-based super-resolution network. Experiments on synthetic datasets demonstrate BrainPuzzle's superior SoS reconstruction accuracy and image completeness, promising advancements in non-invasive brain imaging.

title: AI Pose Analysis and Kinematic Profiling of Range-of-Motion Variations in Resistance Training
summary: This study develops an AI-based pose estimation pipeline to precisely quantify movement kinematics in resistance training, analyzing range-of-motion (ROM) variations in lengthened partial (pROM) versus full ROM (fROM) exercises. It found that pROM involved smaller ROM and shorter durations, particularly during the eccentric phase, with participant-level differences being the primary source of variability. The research introduces a novel, consistent metric, %ROM, demonstrating AI's potential to enhance research and personalize resistance training prescription.

title: Improving Predictive Confidence in Medical Imaging via Online Label Smoothing
summary: This paper introduces Online Label Smoothing (OLS) to mitigate overconfident predictions in deep learning models for medical image classification. OLS dynamically adjusts soft labels throughout training based on the model's own prediction patterns, leading to improved classification accuracy, enhanced calibration, and more robust feature representations.

title: Beyond MedQA: Towards Real-world Clinical Decision Making in the Era of LLMs
summary: This paper proposes a unifying paradigm to evaluate large language models (LLMs) for clinical use, moving beyond simplified Question-Answering (Q&A) datasets like MedQA that underrepresent real-world clinical decision-making. The paradigm characterizes clinical tasks along two dimensions—Clinical Backgrounds and Clinical Questions—to reflect increasing complexity and guide the development of clinically meaningful LLMs.

title: RELATE: A Schema-Agnostic Perceiver Encoder for Multimodal Relational Graphs
summary: This paper introduces RELATE, a novel schema-agnostic Perceiver encoder designed for multimodal relational graph data, common in domains like healthcare. By utilizing shared modality-specific encoders and a Perceiver-style cross-attention mechanism, RELATE generates fixed-size, permutation-invariant node representations, enabling plug-and-play integration with any general-purpose Graph Neural Network (GNN). Evaluations on the RelBench benchmark demonstrate that RELATE achieves performance within 3% of schema-specific encoders while significantly reducing parameter counts by up to 5x, facilitating multi-dataset pretraining and the development of foundation models for complex relational data.

title: Drug-disease networks and drug repurposing
summary: This paper presents a novel drug-disease network, meticulously constructed from diverse data sources, to facilitate drug repurposing. It demonstrates that advanced network-based link prediction methods, especially graph embedding and network model fitting, achieve superior performance in predicting new drug-disease associations, significantly outperforming previous approaches and thus substantially reducing the search space for viable repurposing candidates.

title: FINDER: Feature Inference on Noisy Datasets using Eigenspace Residuals
summary: FINDER is a novel framework designed for robust classification in 'noisy' or 'data-deficient' datasets by integrating fundamental stochastic analysis into feature learning and inference. It constructs "stochastic features" by mapping empirical data to Hilbert spaces, employing the Kosambi-Karhunen-Loève expansion and eigen-decomposition to identify distinct class regions. The method has achieved state-of-the-art breakthroughs in challenging domains, including Alzheimer's Disease stage classification and remote sensing for deforestation.

title: Enhancing Diagnostic Accuracy for Urinary Tract Disease through Explainable SHAP-Guided Feature Selection and Classification
summary: This paper proposes a novel approach to improve diagnostic accuracy for urinary tract diseases, particularly bladder cancer, by integrating SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations)-based feature selection into predictive models. The methodology successfully maintained or enhanced key performance metrics while concurrently increasing model transparency, offering a pathway to more reliable clinical decision support systems.

title: FairGRPO: Fair Reinforcement Learning for Equitable Clinical Reasoning
summary: This paper introduces Fairness-aware Group Relative Policy Optimization (FairGRPO), a hierarchical reinforcement learning approach designed to mitigate performance disparities across demographic groups in medical AI systems. FairGRPO employs adaptive importance weighting and unsupervised clustering to promote equitable learning and address missing demographic labels. Through extensive experiments, FairGRPO significantly reduces predictive parity and improves diagnostic F1 scores across multiple clinical modalities, culminating in the release of a fairness-aware clinical VLLM, FairMedGemma-4B.

title: Enabling Granular Subgroup Level Model Evaluations by Generating Synthetic Medical Time Series
summary:
We present a novel framework for leveraging synthetic ICU time-series data
not only to train but also to rigorously and trustworthily evaluate predictive
models, both at the population level and within fine-grained demographic
subgroups. Building on prior diffusion and VAE-based generators (TimeDiff...

title: Compressing Biology: Evaluating the Stable Diffusion VAE for Phenotypic Drug Discovery
summary: This paper systematically evaluates the Stable Diffusion VAE (SD-VAE) for reconstructing high-dimensional Cell Painting microscopy images, a critical task in phenotypic drug discovery. It demonstrates that SD-VAE effectively preserves phenotypic signals with minimal loss, affirming the suitability of general-purpose generative models for complex biological image analysis. The study further shows that readily available feature extractors like InceptionV3 can match or surpass specialized models in retrieval tasks, thereby simplifying and streamlining future bioimage analysis pipelines.
